moves.1. e4 e5 2. f4 exf4 3. Nf3 d6: Fisher defense. I think alot of people play this move because it is the 'Fisher' move. Black seems to struggle alot in a lot of lines so has to tread very carefully.
moves.4. d4 g5 5. h4 g4 6. Ng1:
As I said earlier could take Ng5 but its very unsound. 

This is the book position which is very strange considering after 6 moves we have a load of passed pawns and no minor or major pieces developed.
moves.6... Nf6: Black attacks e4. Prob hoping to buy time and defend the f pawn on h5.
moves.7. Bxf4: Takes the pawn exchange although could be viewed as a mistake since whites pawn was central and black would have had to waste valuable time & effort defending f pawn.
moves.9... Bg7 10. O-O O-O 11. Bxe4: White has a lead in development with the open file.
moves.14. Ng3 Qf6: Black is restricted here. Unable to develop his pieces he looks to pick up a pawn to make himself feel better!
moves.16. Bxg7: Exposes King. Blacks only developed piece here is his Queen.
moves.16... Kxg7 17. Nxd5 f5: Knight on g3 is safe as would lead to mate in 3 if Queen takes.
moves.18. Qf4 Nc6 19. Nxc7 Rb8 20. Rae1: White is loaded up. Had better development and control of the open and semi open file. Smart play should lead to a victory from here.
moves.20... Kg8 21. d5 Ne7 22. Nh5: ! Black has to take exchange. If he doesnt 23.Qh3 which at best would result in lost Queen.
moves.22... Qxh5 23. Rxe7 b5: Making room to get rook into help out the defense.
moves.24. Rfe1: WHites rooks are now conected on an open file. Black is in serious danger.
moves.24... Rb6 25. d6: Blocks the rooks involvement and the prospect of promotion could become a real thorn in blacks side.
moves.25... Qh4 26. g3 Qf6: A nice little finishing combo for yall.

gameName: Kings Gambit (G4) - Crushing the fisher defence.
